float.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to stay or move on the surface of a liquid without sinking
float.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I wasn’t sure if the raft would float.
She spent the afternoon floating on her back in the pool.
A couple of broken branches floated past us.
float.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to put something on the surface of a liquid so that it does not sink
float.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The logs are trimmed and then floated down the river.
float.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if something floats, it moves slowly through the air or stays up in the air
float.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I looked up at the clouds floating in the sky.
Leaves floated gently down from the trees.
float.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if sounds or smells float somewhere, people in another place can hear or smell them
float.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The sound of her voice came floating down from an upstairs window.
float.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to walk in a slow light graceful way
float.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Rachel floated around the bedroom in a lace nightgown.
float.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to suggest an idea or plan in order to see if people like it
float.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: We first floated the idea back in 1992.
float.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: if the government of a country floats its money, the value of the money is allowed to change freely in relation to money from other countries
float.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Russia decided to float the rouble on the foreign exchange market.
float.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to sell shares in a company or business to the public for the first time
float.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: The company will be floated on the stock market next year.
float.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to write a cheque when you do not have enough money in the bank to pay it
float.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a large vehicle that is decorated to drive through the streets as part of a special event
float.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: We stood and watched the Carnival floats drive past.
float.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a sweet drink that has ice cream floating in it
float.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a small light object that floats on the surface of the water, used by people trying to catch fish to show where their line is
float.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a flat light object that you can rest part of your body on in water to help you learn to swim
float.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: a small amount of money that someone in a shop keeps so that they have enough money to give change to people
float.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: a time when shares in a company are made available for people to buy for the first time
float.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: a time when you sit in a flotation tank in order to treat illness or injury, or to relax
float.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to sell new shares, bonds etc on a financial market
float.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: To finance the expansion, the airport has floated $30 billion in bonds, which should cover 75% of construction costs.
float.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to sell shares in a company on a stockmarket for the first time
float.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The price of the company’s shares on the day it floated on the stock market beat all expectations.
float.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: if the government of a country floats its currency, or if the currency floats, its value is allowed to change in relation to other currencies after a period of time when it has been fixed
float.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: He had been responsible for sweeping economic reforms, including floating the Australian dollar and deregulating the financial system.
float.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: if a price, amount etc floats, it moves up or down slowly
float.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: The oil market let crude prices float lower.
Throughout the 1970s, the stock and bond markets floated up.
float.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: when shares, bonds etc are sold on a financial market, or when a company sells shares for the first time
float.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The board is still talking with its investment bankers about the timing and terms of the float, which is expected to value the company at between $3 billion and $4 billion.
float.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: when a currency is allowed to change in value in relation to others
float.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: Until the float of sterling in 1972 there were few restrictions on investment within the sterling area.
float.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: the money made available to banks while customers’ cheques go through the banking system
float.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: Many consumers have long believed that bankers have lengthened the check-clearing process to use the float for their own benefit.
float.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: the amount of notes and coins in the TILL of a shop, restaurant etc when they open for business
float.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: Cash floats should be rechecked to ensure that cashiers have enough change for the evening business.
float.translation[3].definitions[4].defi: a small amount of money that is kept in an office for making small payments
float.translation[3].definitions[4].exam: A business credit card removes the need for a cash float.
